diagrams.description: A timeline showing the history of Environmental Engineering.
diagrams.mermaid_code:
timeline
    title: The History of Environmental Engineering
    section: 19th Century - The Sanitary Revolution
        1842: Edwin Chadwick's "Sanitary Report" in London
        1854: John Snow links cholera to contaminated water in London
        Late 1800s: Development of water and wastewater treatment plants
    section: Early-to-Mid 20th Century - Air Pollution
        1930: Meuse Valley fog in Belgium
        1948: Donora smog in Pennsylvania
        1952: The Great Smog of London
        1955: Air Pollution Control Act in the U.S.
    section: Late 20th Century - The Modern Environmental Movement
        1962: Rachel Carson's "Silent Spring"
        1970: The first Earth Day
        1970: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is established
        1980: The Superfund Act (CERCLA)
    section: 21st Century - Sustainability and Climate Change
        1997: The Kyoto Protocol
        2000s: Focus on renewable energy and sustainable design
        2015: The Paris Agreement
